Provider in a Primary Care Clinic

chapter.title: Clinical Stability Assessment
chapter.para: This documentation template is not applicable for unstable patients

row.entry: Ongoing resting chest pain for > 20 minutes with ST elevation or depression on ECG
Onset of new resting chest pain episodes within the past week
New onset, recurrent chest pain with minimal exertion over the past 2 months
Previously stable exertional angina now occurring with minimal activity over the past 2 months

Condition:elm:Or (elm:And( elm:Property("ongoingRestingChestPain" from: elm:ParameterRef(Responses)) elm:Property("onsetOfNewRestingChestPain" from: elm:ParameterRef(Responses))) elm:And( elm:Property("onsetOfRecurrentChestPain" from: elm:ParameterRef(Responses)) elm:Property("previouslyStableExertionalAngina" from: elm:ParameterRef(Responses))))

โ This documentation template is not applicable for use with patients who are unstable based on clinician judgement. Examples of unstable patients include, but are not limited to, patients with chest pain pattern suggestive of ACS (e.g., those with new onset resting CP, CP with minimal exertion, new unstable angina pattern, ST-segment elevation, nonโST-segment elevation myocardial infarction on ECG, or suspected aortic dissection), and patients with any of the following symptoms or findings:
topicFocus: Hospital-based outpatient emergency care center 73770003
โ The user will complete this section for a patient determined to be unstable.
Rationale for determining that the patient was unstable, noting that the patient was transferred to the nearest emergency department immediately.
โ Provide a link to the American Heart Association Risk Calculator
American Heart Association Risk Caclulator link

โ For this documentation template, please assess the patientโs 10-year cardiovascular disease risk using either clinical judgement or a risk calculator such as that provided by the AHA. Patientโs 10-Year Cardiovascular Disease Risk
History of prior cardiac evaluations (e.g., prior hospitalization or evaluations for: chest pain, rule/out MI, angina, heart failure, etc.)
Results of prior cardiac diagnostic procedures performed (resting ECG, echocardiogram, stress testing (echo, nuclear, MRI), CCT or angiography)
Physical Exam, Pertinent Positive and Negative Findings
Details of previous invasive diagnostic procedures and resulting interventions (e.g., angiography, PCI/Stents, or CABG)
Each item in this section needs to include an expression, and a model (phenomenon testing result, thyroid result testing function measurement date within an interval of now to two years ago
Basic Metabolic Profile Lab Result between now and up-to 2 years ago
Complete Blood Count Lab Result between now and up-to 2 years ago
Lipid Profile Lab Result between now and up-to 2 years ago
Thyroid Function Testing Lab Result between now and up-to 2 years ago
Troponin Lab Result between now and up-to 2 years ago
Brain Natriuretic Peptide Lab Result between now and up-to 2 years ago
D-dimer Lab Result between now and up-to 2 years ago

Images and diagnostic studies older than one year are not considered for inclusion in this documentation template. For this documentation template, the following information should be included, if available from the prior 1 year. Image and result text should be attached automatically if they are is provided for the 12-Lead Electrocardiogram Interpretation field.
Attach or link results: 12-Lead Electrocardiogram Interpretation
Attach or link results: Stress Electrocardiography Interpretation
Attach or link images: Stress Electrocardiography
Attach or link results: Resting Echocardiogram/Doppler Interpretation
Attach or link images: Resting Echocardiogram/Doppler
Attach or link results: Stress Echocardiogram Interpretation
Attach or link images: Stress Echocardiogram
Attach or link results: Stress MPI Interpretation
Attach or link images: Stress MPI
Attach or link results: Rest MRI Interpretation
Attach or link images: Rest MRI
Attach or link results: Stress MRI Interpretation
Attach or link images: Stress MRI
Attach or link results: Chest CT results
Attach or link images: Chest CT images
Attach or link results: Coronary/Cardiac CTA Interpretation
Attach or link images: Coronary/Cardiac CTA
Attach or link results: X-Ray Chest Interpretation
Attach or link images: X-Ray Chest

Display Text
If a code is used multiple times in the KNART, only the display text of the first instance is shown.

References
Count of the number of times the given code system and code pair is used in the KNART.
NM Heart perfusion W stress and W radionuclide IV
Cardiac stress test EKG study Type [L]
CTA Heart and Coronary arteries W contrast IV

A group of related alternative actions is a sentence group if the item referenced by the action is the same in all the actions, and each action simply constitutes a different variation on how to specify the details for that item. For example, two actions that could be in a SentenceGroup are "aspirin, 500 mg, 2 times per day" and "aspirin, 300 mg, 3 times per day". In both cases, aspirin is the item referenced by the action, and the two actions represent two different options for how aspirin might be ordered for the patient. Note that a SentenceGroup would almost always have an associated selection behavior of "AtMostOne", unless it's a required action, in which case, it would be "ExactlyOne".
A group with this behavior logically groups its sub-elements, and may be shown as a visual group to the end user, but it is not required to do so.
Any group marked with this behavior should be displayed as a visual group to the end user.
Any number of the items in the group may be chosen, from zero to all.
All the items in the group must be selected as a single unit.
All the items in the group are meant to be chosen as a single unit: either all must be selected by the end user, or none may be selected.
The end user must choose one and only one of the selectable items in the group. The user may not choose none of the items in the group.
The end user may choose zero or at most one of the items in the group.
The end user must choose a minimum of one, and as many additional as desired.
An action with this behavior must be included in the actions processed by the end user; the end user may not choose not to include this action.
An action with this behavior may be included in the set of actions processed by the end user.
An action with this behavior must be included in the set of actions processed by the end user, unless the end user provides documentation as to why the action was not included.

An action with this behavior is one of the most frequent actions that is, or should be, included by an end user, for the particular context in which the action occurs. The system displaying the action to the end user should consider "pre-checking" such an action as a convenience for the user.

An action with this behavior is one of the less frequent actions included by the end user, for the particular context in which the action occurs. The system displaying the actions to the end user would typically not "pre-check" such an action.
An action with this behavior may only be completed once.
An action with this behavior may be repeated multiple times.
This item, in a list entry, allows the user to enter a fill in value that is not present in the set of presented choices.
For a particular action or action group, specifies whether the elements are read only.
